medical_history.chief_complaint: Asymptomatic children with MEN1 mutations found to have nonfunctioning pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors.
medical_history.history_of_present_illness: Two asymptomatic children, aged 12 and 14 years, were diagnosed with pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors. The 14-year-old girl had oligomenorrhea, hyperprolactinemia, and mild hypercalcemia, not previously symptomatic. The tumors were found incidentally during evaluation.
medical_history.past_medical_history: Both patients had inherited MEN1 mutations. The 14-year-old had additional primary hyperparathyroidism and a microprolactinoma. The 12-year-old had a nonfunctioning pituitary microadenoma.
medical_history.family_history: The 14-year-old girl's father had facial angiofibromas, and her family had a history of MEN1. The 7-year-old girlâ€™s father died from a metastatic pancreatic tumor at age 33.
